job_title: Activities Coordinator in Chula Vista, CA
pros: Management is accessible and cares about their employees. Good compensation with recent additions that make us feel more valued. Really good work environment with a great team for the most part. A company with an excellent reputation in the field who truly make a difference for many seniors from diverse socioeconomic backgrounds.
cons: Short staffing puts a strain on the running of the facility at no fault to our company just how it is post covid. Some positions need to be redefined to help manage workload and/or utilize some employees more effectively.

job_title: Certified Nursing Assistant CNA in Chula Vista, CA
pros: Starting pay is better than most facilities $19
cons: very stressful, call-outs nearly every day, drama in the workplace, not enough staff and help to care for residents, and they admit too many residents while still short-staffed.

job_title: Certified Nursing Assistant CNA in San Diego, CA
pros: Not a heavy work load.
cons: Short staff Relies on registry

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Chula Vista, CA
pros: Great place to work. Just like everywhere, there were rough times but coming together as a team, we were able to get through them. As a manager, it was nice to go around for the first two weeks and meet everyone and learn what the different roles throughout the company are. How often do you get to sit one on one with the CEO for 2 hours and discuss YOU and the importance of your role and what the expectations are from the top? Interactions with upper management were frequent. When they visited my buidling, they would always pop their head in and say Hi. They even stopped by on my last day to wish me luck on the future. Amazing people!
cons: Sometimes the hours can be long, but nothing compared to a restaurant. I only put this because I had to put something down. Even if you worked the entire day from open to close, it is only 15 hours and that is easy to do in some restaurants daily. I think this only happened once the entire time I worked there.

job_title: Receptionist in San Diego, CA
pros: Friendly and helpful. Will try to accommodate your needs.
cons: No holiday pay or extra incentive.

job_title: Server in San Diego, CA
pros:
-nice atmosphere

job_title: Outreach Specialist in Eugene, OR
pros: Friendly people to work with.
cons: overly friendly at times before i have my coffee

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros: Exciting opportunity to serve seniors! Very rewarding. Great front line and middle management team.
cons: Executive leadership is not reflective of the populations we serve. The executive team is very out of touch with frontline operations which poses a barrier to having the resources needed to provide the highest quality of care to frail, older adults who depend on our care.

job_title: Fitness and Activity Coordinator in Chula Vista, CA
pros: I have been with the company for 5 1/2 years and feel blessed to be part of an organization that provides such comprehensive care for seniors from different economic circumstances. My position is one that I thoroughly enjoy and to be able to serve seniors in such a caring, heart centered culture is a wonderful opportunity. There are always challenges in a work environment but I have always felt supported by my managers to find a way through and they are always accessible to me.
cons: At times communication can be convoluted but the accessibility of management makes that an easy fix.

job_title: Social Worker in San Diego, CA
pros: hours not the best no room for promotion
cons: people are nice but not room for advancement

job_title: PCA Personal Care Assistant in Greenville, PA
pros: Love the residents and most co-workers! They make the job worth it. The workers care and helping and getting to know residents is great.
cons: The administration is horrible. They don't seem to actually care about their employees. The ceo seems to but not the admin. If they mess up your schedule they tell you to deal with it. Unprofessional. They expect you to go beyond for st paul's and then do the bare minimum to help employees. They get paid salary but refuse to work anything outside of their 9-5 jobs and force employees to bend around their comforts.

review_title: One of the Best Places I have ever worked!
job_title: Business Development and Sales in San Diego, CA
pros: St. Paul's had provided me an amazing setting to grow in Healthcare Business development. I have never felt more welcome in a workplace with every colleague I interact with. They support me whenever I need it and encourage my personal and professional development. I work 35 Miles North of my building and am happy to take that drive every day to do the work I do
cons: At the risk of sounding too Cliché, I have not found any Cons in working here so far.

job_title: Certified Nursing Assistant CNA in Chula Vista, CA
pros: Great working environment with good team work for the most part; Effective Supervisor and Program Director; Hard work and extra effort are recognized; They try to promote from within providing upward career mobility.
cons: Sometimes bureaucratic red tape slows things down.

review_title: I am a CNA at St Pauls

Great company to work for 
Career advancements

job_title: Certified Nursing Assistant CNA in San Diego, CA
pros: Pays more than most companies

job_title: Registered Nurse in San Diego, CA
pros:
1. Tight-knit working environment allows for team bonding with your department. Great environment if you have initiative in your job! Those who do not have initiative will be quickly weeded out.

2. Frequent interaction with the same participants allows for continuity of care. Participants become like family. Great meaning and satisfaction to your job.

3. Solid and dependable hours. What RN gets to work M-F 8-4:30?

4. You can make it a healthy working environment if you keep your head down and serve your patients.
cons:
1. General distrust of upper management. Recent employee survey indicates this...please do something about it.

2. Lack of clearly defined roles and responsibilities allow for "finger pointing" and miscommunication among staff.

3. Decisions/management is easily swayed by those who "push" hardest rather than objective data.

4. Due to being such a small company, morale is greatly affected by drama and staffing changes. It's like a roller coaster.

5. Employees are generally seen as expendable (from the front-line point of view). HR will walk you out humiliatingly without hesitation.

job_title: Physician Assistant in San Diego, CA
pros: There are a lot of benefits for working for St. Paul's PACE. First the mission for caring for seniors that are high risk is rewarding. Also the culture of the company is positive from the top down. PACE takes a group approach to caring for patients with Physical therapists, Occupational therapists, Social workers, dietitians, home care team, ect that shows how interdisciplinary care can benefit patients. The work environment is collaborative and positive and I look forward to coming to work everyday to care for undeserved seniors.
cons: This is a nonprofit so while the pay is competitive the benefits package including paid time off and healthcare has some room for improvement. As for the workflow, there is a steep learning curve for understanding all of the differences within the PACE model compared to traditional clinics.

job_title: Day Center CNA Supervisor in Chula Vista, CA
pros: It's being an amazing experience to work in this company, I started 7 years ago as a Medical Record and now I am a Day Center Supervisor!! This company open a door of oportunities to grow and continue with your education goals. Working at St. Paul's Senior Services gave you the best benefit or reward that a person can have... Changing a peoples life by serving, helping and being able to see a smile and gratitude on our senior face!!! That is what this company offer. Love to work at St. Paul's Senior Services and grateful to have this amazing opportunity.
cons: There is no downs to work in this company.

job_title: RN Supervisor in San Diego, CA
pros: I work at St. Paul's Skilled Nursing Facility. This is a non-profit company, which means it is not some corporate entity with shareholders that come before patients/employees. I actually feel truly valued for the first time in my nursing career, and when I need something for my patients, I actually get it (most of the time...)! The patients are wonderful, the staff are SUPER nice and mostly helpful, and it is a nice, small building.
cons: Many of the companies policies are outdated. They are far too lenient on staff who call off, which makes it harder for everyone. There was a lack of real leadership for a time, and staff have become kind of accustomed to doing as they please

job_title: Clinic RN in San Diego, CA
pros: The patients and team work. All the different patients that come through the clinic/day center are so unique and different, I love that we get to care for them and make their day a better one. I love all their stories and thoughtfulness when they see you. The clinic team works like a well oiled machine. I love that I can ask a question and someone knows the answer. We are supported by a great team of medical staff that goes above and beyond the call.  It is so great to know that everyone is willing to work together to come to a solution.
cons: We can't take in everyone.

job_title: Chaplain in El Cajon, CA
pros: I work for PACE.  PACE stands for Providing All Inclusive Care for the Elderly.  I've been here for a year now, and from the beginning have loved it.  The staff is caring and kind, skilled in its various disciplines, treating each other with respect and the joy that springs from doing excellent work in an environment that encourages communication, teamwork and creativity.  In turn, the team members of every persuasion treat our participants with the love, kindness, and skilled service that we would want our own family members to receive.
cons: In my experience, there are no negatives.

review_title: A place for growth both Professionally and Personal!
job_title: Quality Assurance Specialist in San Diego, CA
pros: Employees create a community that seems more like family. In addition, the organization provides growth opportunities and promotes a sense of transparency and accountability that aligns with a growth mindset.
cons: Working here is difficult finding cons. However, with rapid growth... employees feel a bit of growing pains but other than that, its a pretty great place to work.

job_title: Quality Assurance Specialist in San Diego, CA
pros:
St. Paul's PACE is a great company as it is moving towards an innovative direction when providing quality care to its patients through out San Diego county. Leadership is continuously searching new ways on how to improve services enhancing the patient experience in a meaningful way. 
Employees are mostly motivated and eager in collaborating expertise and experience at each of the disciplines involved in the continuity of care a patient has.
cons: As a seasoned organization, the only con one can think of is limited resources on investing in competitive technology but again, there is so much opportunity for growth.

job_title: Physician Assistant in San Diego, CA
pros: Excellent/reputable providers on staff (MD/NP/PA); great supervisors and directors; great work environment; great work-life balance; good pay; desirable hours; able to spend time with patients and focus on all medical needs; unique coordinated team-based care with excellent patient access and coverage to resources including: transportation, psychiatry/psychology, PT/OT/ST, SW, podiatry, dental, optometry, specialists, medications, etc;
cons: No major cons. PTO is somewhat limited, especially when newly employed but improves over time; patient population is typically very complicated with multiple comorbidities, psychiatric illness and substance abuse.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros: Positive team of caring employees dedicated to the mission of providing quality senior care.  Great team spirit.
cons: That we have to deal with negative comments about our organization from disgruntled employees who lack any level of compassion for seniors and were let go because they were rude to family members.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros: Caring and compassionate company that values longevity. Cares about employee feedback. CEO is amazing and goes above and beyond for residents needs, she would never ask you to do anything that she would not do herself.
cons: Parking at Bankers Hill location. Some members of upper management (CAO, COO) do not seem to know or understand what the employees do or the importance of their jobs.

job_title: Director in San Diego, CA
pros: Great team, all focusing on the mission of helping the most frail and needy. Team/leadership makes decisions based on what the "right thing to do" is. What could be better?
cons: Very few, if any. The pandemic has made it difficult to strengthening relationships and work collaboration, but SPSS is constantly adjusting and growing.

job_title: Site Director in San Diego, CA
pros: I am having a difficult time thinking of any pros. The company values are non-existent, the leadership is absent, there is not training, and only the most obsequeious of losers are promoted. This is the worst job I have ever had the most phoney non-profit I have every had any experience with and I have worked for non-profits for most of my forty-year career.
cons:
Working here has been a nightmare. This is far and away the worst experience I have ever had. I was the Director of their PACE program and led a team of approximately fifty employees. The organization forces people to pray before every meeting. They force salaried employees to "volunteer" at their functions and coerce staff to donate to the organization via payroll deductions. For me, the most horrendous (and very telling) experince was having the Executive Director stand at the entryway of the annual Christmas Party and make employees go and wash their hands before entering the party. I was recently forced to "volunteer" at their annual LUV Gala where, I noticed, donors and attendees were not forced to visit the restroom prior to entering the the event. Staff "volunteers" were relegated to a dingy room where they had a buffet of cold past and some sloppy already-dressed wilting salad. I felt like the maid in Downton Abbey. Aside from the twenty-minute break we were given, most "volunteers" were forced to stand for five hours.

Benefits are horrible. There is very little choice for medical insurance - two HMOs, Kaiser and Sharp, where the provider is the same as the insurance company. Whe kind of care does one get when the insurance company paying controls the doctors. Yes, terrible health care. Leave time consists of seventeen days per year TOTAL - to be used for holidays, personal, sick, or vacation - so basically the ten holidays everyone gets off plus seven more days of sick, personal, and vacation combined. I can't tell you difficult it was to attract decent staff when the benefits are so paltry.

Beyond that, I feel like the care this organization provides to the elderly community they are supposed to be serving is horrible. Everything is based around money money money for the organization so benefits the elderly residents are supposed to be receiving are not given. I think an interesting point is the fact that this is supposed to a non-profit organization but I noticed that, whenever I have to order or purchase anything, we pay taxes. Non-profit organization are tax exempt so I have always felt like something fishy is going on - like they are lying to their donors. I asked about this almost as soon as I started working there but got hushed up that and every other time I asked.

Because St. Paul's is such a horrible place to work, the only staff who stay on for any length of time are pretty lacking - again, only obsequeious lackeys stay on and/or move up in this organization. There is very little real leadership because of this. The Executive Director of the organization and the Executive Director of PACE sit in their respective offices all day with their doors closed. They are completely inaccessible to staff and totally out of touch with what actually goes on in the organization.

I cannot possible stress enough how awful my experience with this place has been. I have finally had it and am feverishly searching for a new job.

review_title: Meaningful work with talented staff, who work to provide broad services to seniors & those in need after hospitalization
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros: A diverse staff, wide range of services and activities for residents/clients, a family-environment for both staff and clients, and a genuine concern for everyone's best interests.  When a resident hurts, the staff truly feel it.
cons: Young (professionally) staff do not have the full expertise as more seasoned staff do in other areas.

job_title: LVN in El Cajon, CA
pros: I've been employed with St Paul's PACE since 2009. I started as a home care CNA and went back to school for my LVN. I was promoted as soon as I became licensed. It's a great company to grow with. I truly love what I do and helping our seniors!!
cons: Benefits package can be improved.

job_title: Nurse Practitioner in San Diego, CA
pros: I like my boss and coworkers. Really supportive staff. Great teamwork. I have been here for 2 years.
cons: I would like more PTO days. There are not that many because you have to use a PTO day for days that the clinic is closed (like Christmas/Thanksgiving/etc).

pros: Great place to work. Leadership team is fantastic providing a safe and fun place to work even in this time of COVID 19. Look forward to going to work each day.

review_title: I loved this job because I really enjoy helping those who can't do things on their own anymore.
